Four-body central configurations with one pair of opposite sides parallel

Manuele Santoprete Department of Mathematics, Wilfrid Laurier University E-mail: msantopr@wlu.ca
Abstract

We study four-body central configurations with one pair of opposite sides parallel. We use a novel constraint to write the central configuration equations in this special case, using distances as variables. We prove that, for a given ordering of the mutual distances, a trapezoidal central configuration must have a certain partial ordering of the masses. We also show that if opposite masses of a four-body trapezoidal central configuration are equal, then the configuration has a line of symmetry and it must be a kite. In contrast to the general four-body case, we show that if the two adjacent masses bounding the shortest side are equal, then the configuration must be an isosceles trapezoid, and the remaining two masses must also be equal.

  2. 2 Another Planarity Conditions

  4. 4 Relationship to Cayley-Menger
  5. 5 Some Applications of the c.c. equations

Viewing Î»ğœ†\lambda as a Lagrange multiplier, a central configuration is simply a critical point of Uğ‘ˆU subject to the constraint Iğ¼I equals a constant.

A central configuration is planar if the four points P1,P2,P3subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2subscriptğ‘ƒ3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3}, and P4subscriptğ‘ƒ4P_{4} lie on the same plane. Equations (3), and (4) also describe planar central configurations provided ğªiâˆˆâ„2subscriptğªğ‘–superscriptâ„2\mathbf{q}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{2} for i=1,â€¦â€‹4ğ‘–1â€¦4i=1,\ldots 4. We say that a planar configuration is degenerate if two or more points coincide, or if more than two points lie on the same line. Non-degenerate planar configurations can be classified as either concave or convex. A concave configuration has one point which is located strictly inside the convex hull of the other three, whereas a convex configuration does not have a point contained in the convex hull of the other three points. Any convex configuration determines a convex quadrilateral (for a precise definition of quadrilateral see for example [5]). In a planar convex configuration we say that the points are ordered sequentially if they are numbered consecutively while traversing the boundary of the corresponding convex quadrilateral. In this paper we are interested in studying trapezoidal central configurations, that is, those c.c.â€™s for which two of the opposite sides are parallel (see Figure 1). Non-degenerate trapezoidal central configurations are necessarily convex.

The four body problem has a long and distinguished history. In 1900 Dziobek derived equations for central configurations of four bodies with distances as variables [14]. In 1932 McMillan and Bartky used similar equations to obtain many important new results [19]. In 1996 Albouy [1, 2] gave a complete classifications of the four-body c.c.â€™s with equal masses. More recently, in 2006 Hampton and Moeckel [16] proved the finiteness of the number of c.c.â€™s. Other recent results of note, concerning four-body c.c.â€™s in the case some of the masses are equal, were obtained by the present author and Perez-Chavela, [20], Albouy, Fu and Sun [4], and Fernandes, Llibre and Mello [15]. Further results for the four-body were recently attained by Cors and Roberts [9], Corbera, Cors and Roberts [8], Deng, Li and Zhang [11, 12] and Xie [24], just to mention a few. Particularly important for this paper is the work of Cors and Roberts [9] which inspired for the approach we take here. Additionally, certain bifurcations in the four-body problem, and several planarity conditions and their applications to four-body c.c.â€™s were obtained by the present author in [21] and [22], respectively.

Let ğ«=(r12,r13,r14,r23,r24,r34)âˆˆ(â„+)6ğ«subscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ13subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23subscriptğ‘Ÿ24subscriptğ‘Ÿ34superscriptsuperscriptâ„6\mathbf{r}=(r_{12},r_{13},r_{14},r_{23},r_{24},r_{34})\in(\mathbb{R}^{+})^{6} be a vector of mutual distances. The conditions for which such vector determines a realizable configuration of four bodies in Euclidean space can be expressed by the Cayley-Menger criterion, that we state below. The Cayley-Menger determinant of four points P1,â€¦â€‹P4subscriptğ‘ƒ1â€¦subscriptğ‘ƒ4P_{1},\ldots P_{4} is

Hâ€‹(ğ«)=|0111110r122r132r1421r1220r232r2421r132r2320r3421r142r242r3420.|.ğ»ğ«matrix0111110subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ212subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ213subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2141subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2120subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ223subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2241subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ213subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2230subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2341subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ214subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ224subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2340H(\mathbf{r})=\begin{vmatrix}0&1&1&1&1\\ 1&0&r^{2}_{12}&r^{2}_{13}&r^{2}_{14}\\ 1&r^{2}_{12}&0&r^{2}_{23}&r^{2}_{24}\\ 1&r^{2}_{13}&r^{2}_{23}&0&r^{2}_{34}\\ 1&r^{2}_{14}&r^{2}_{24}&r^{2}_{34}&0.\end{vmatrix}.

A configuration is geometrically realizable if and only if the Cayley-Menger determinant of each subconfiguration of two or more points is â‰¥0absent0\geq 0 when the number of points is even, and â‰¤0absent0\leq 0 when it is odd. See, for instance, the book of Blumenthal [7] or Theorem 9.7.3.4 and Exercise 9.14.23 in [6]. Note that an equivalent characterization can be given in terms of Borchardtâ€™s quadratic form, see [3, 23]. In the remainder of this paper we assume that ğ«ğ«\mathbf{r} is geometrically realizable.

In the four-body problem the mutual distances are not independent so that describing planar four-body central configurations requires an additional constraint. Following Dziobek [14] it is customary to use the following planarity condition,

Planarity Condition 1.

P1,P2,P3,P4âˆˆâ„3subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2subscriptğ‘ƒ3subscriptğ‘ƒ4superscriptâ„3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3},P_{4}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} are coplanar if and only if the Cayley-Menger determinant determined by these four points is 00, that is, Hâ€‹(ğ«)=0ğ»ğ«0H(\mathbf{r})=0.

In this paper we use a different constraint that not only gives planarity of the configuration, but also restricts the configuration to be trapezoidal. This planarity conditions complements the list given in [22]. Our approach parallels the treatment of the co-circular for body problem given by Cors and Roberts in [9]. The new constraint is introduced in Section 2. In Section 3 we derive the equations for the trapezoidal central configurations. In Section 4 we study the relationship between the Cayley-Menger constraint and the constraint used in the paper, and show that, as expected, the gradients of these restrictions are collinear at trapezoidal configurations. In Section 5 we prove that, for a given ordering of the mutual distances, a trapezoidal central configuration must have a certain partial ordering of the masses. This result is by necessity weaker than the analogous result for co-circular configurations where one obtains a total ordering (see [9]). We also prove that if opposite masses of a four-body trapezoidal central configuration are equal, then the configuration has a line of symmetry and is a kite. This is a special case of the well known result of Albouy, Fu and Sun [4]. A similar result also holds in the case the two adjacent masses bounding the shortest side are equal. In this case the configuration is an isosceles trapezoid, and the remaining two masses must also be equal. Finally, we show that, in contrast to the co-circular case, when the two adjacent masses bounding the longest side are equal there are asymmetric solutions.

We remark that if one imposes Ptolemyâ€™s condition to study co-circular configurations, as done in [9], it is possible to see that any realizable configuration satisfying Ptolemyâ€™s must be planar as a consequence of the Cayley-Menger criterion.

Assuming the six mutual distances determine an actual configuration in the plane, this equation is necessary and sufficient for the existence of a four-body planar central configuration. Further restrictions are needed to ensure that the masses are positive.

Reasoning as in [9] it is possible to show that positivity of the masses implies that each side of the quadrilateral is shorter in length than either diagonal, and that the shortest exterior side must lie opposite the longest. Then, the longest side will be either one of the parallel sides or one of the remaining exterior sides. In the former case suppose r14subscriptğ‘Ÿ14r_{14} is the longest exterior side, then we have that r23subscriptğ‘Ÿ23r_{23} is the shortest, and thus

|r14âˆ’r23|>|r34âˆ’r12|.subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23subscriptğ‘Ÿ34subscriptğ‘Ÿ12|r_{14}-r_{23}|>|r_{34}-r_{12}|.

However, four lengths can constitute the consecutive sides of a non-parallelogram trapezoid, with r12subscriptğ‘Ÿ12r_{12} and r34subscriptğ‘Ÿ34r_{34} the lengths of the parallel sides, only when

|r14âˆ’r23|<|r34âˆ’r12|<r14+r23,subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23subscriptğ‘Ÿ34subscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23|r_{14}-r_{23}|<|r_{34}-r_{12}|<r_{14}+r_{23},

which contradicts the previous inequality. A similar reasoning shows that r23subscriptğ‘Ÿ23r_{23} cannot be the longest exterior side. Hence, in a trapezoidal central configuration, one of the legs cannot be the longest exterior side.

In the latter case, without any loss of generality, we can label the bodies so that r12subscriptğ‘Ÿ12r_{12} is the longest exterior side-length. Then, positivity of the masses implies that

we find that at a trapezoidal central configuration

Proposition 2.

For any trapezoidal central configuration ğ«ğ«\mathbf{r}

âˆ‡Hâ€‹(ğ«)=8â€‹h2â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ«).âˆ‡ğ»ğ«8superscriptâ„2âˆ‡ğ¹ğ«\nabla H(\mathbf{r})=8h^{2}~{}\nabla F(\mathbf{r}).

In other words, on the set of geometrically realizable vectors for which both Hğ»H and Fğ¹F vanish, the gradients of these two functions are parallel.

Note that a isosceles trapezoid central configurations is both a trapezoidal and co-circular. Therefore taking the proposition above together with Lemma 2.1 in [9] implies that on the set of geometrically realizable vectors for which Hğ»H, Fğ¹F and P=r12â€‹r34+r14â€‹r23âˆ’r13â€‹r24ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ34subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23subscriptğ‘Ÿ13subscriptğ‘Ÿ24P=r_{12}r_{34}+r_{14}r_{23}-r_{13}r_{24} vanish the gradients of these three functions are parallel. Thus, the codimension one level surfaces defined by the equations H=0ğ»0H=0, F=0ğ¹0F=0, and P=0ğ‘ƒ0P=0 meet tangentially at the isosceles trapezoid configurations.

5 Some Applications of the c.c. equations

In this section we apply equations (3)-(4) to obtain interesting results in the cases some of the masses are equal. We begin with two propositions that have a very simple proof.

Proposition 3.

If m1=m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2m_{1}=m_{2} and m3=m4subscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š4m_{3}=m_{4}, then the corresponding trapezoidal central configuration must be an isosceles trapezoid.

Proof.

By using the two equations (13) it follows that that the diagonals are equal, that is, r13=r24subscriptğ‘Ÿ13subscriptğ‘Ÿ24r_{13}=r_{24}. To conclude the proof it is enough to observe that a trapezoid with diagonals of equal length is an isosceles trapezoid. âˆ

Proposition 4.

If m1=m3subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š3m_{1}=m_{3} and m2=m4subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š4m_{2}=m_{4}, then the corresponding trapezoidal central configuration must be a rhombus.

Proof.

By using the two equations (14) it follows that r14=r23subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23r_{14}=r_{23}. It follows that the quadrilateral is either a isosceles trapezoid or a rhombus.

If it is an isosceles trapezoid the diagonals have equal length, and from equation (13) it follows that the masses are all equal. From the first of equation (21) it follows that the bases are equal, that is r12=r34subscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ34r_{12}=r_{34}. Moreover, from equations (12) and (13) we have that all the exterior sides are equal. The quadrilateral is then a square. In either case the quadrilateral is a rhombus.

âˆ

Cors and Roberts [9] proved that in any co-circular configuration with a given ordering of the mutual distances the masses must be ordered in a precise fashion, that is, the set of masses {m1,m2,m3,m4}subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š4\{m_{1},m_{2},m_{3},m_{4}\} is totally ordered. We now want to obtain an similar result in the case of trapezoidal central configurations. Because of the different geometry, however, it turns out that the set of masses is not totally ordered. In fact, in this case, it is only possible to obtain the following weaker result

Theorem 1.

Any trapezoid central configuration in Î©Î©\Omega satisfies

m3â‰¤m4â‰¤m2andm3â‰¤m1.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š4subscriptğ‘š2andsubscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š1m_{3}\leq m_{4}\leq m_{2}\quad\mbox{and}\quad m_{3}\leq m_{1}.

Before proving this we present two important inequalities needed in the proof of the theorem.

Lemma 2.

Let Ï•:Iâ†’â„:italic-Ï•â†’ğ¼â„\phi:I\to\mathbb{R} be a decreasing differentiable function on an interval IâŠ‚â„ğ¼â„I\subset\mathbb{R}. Suppose that x1â‰¤x2â‰¤x3â‰¤x4subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¥3subscriptğ‘¥4x_{1}\leq x_{2}\leq x_{3}\leq x_{4}, then

Ï•â€‹(x2)âˆ’Ï•â€‹(x3)Ï•â€‹(x1)âˆ’Ï•â€‹(x4)â‰¤1.italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥2italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥3italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥1italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥41\frac{\phi(x_{2})-\phi(x_{3})}{\phi(x_{1})-\phi(x_{4})}\leq 1.
Proof.

The proof is straightforward. Since x1â‰¤x2â‰¤x3â‰¤x4subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¥3subscriptğ‘¥4x_{1}\leq x_{2}\leq x_{3}\leq x_{4} and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is decreasing, then Ï•â€‹(x1)â‰¥Ï•â€‹(x2)â‰¥Ï•â€‹(x3)â‰¥Ï•â€‹(x4)italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥1italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥2italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥3italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥4\phi(x_{1})\geq\phi(x_{2})\geq\phi(x_{3})\geq\phi(x_{4}). It follows that Ï•â€‹(x1)âˆ’Ï•â€‹(x4)â‰¥Ï•â€‹(x2)âˆ’Ï•â€‹(x3)italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥1italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥4italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥2italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥3\phi(x_{1})-\phi(x_{4})\geq\phi(x_{2})-\phi(x_{3}). Since both sides of the inequality are positive we obtain

Ï•â€‹(x2)âˆ’Ï•â€‹(x3)Ï•â€‹(x1)âˆ’Ï•â€‹(x4)â‰¤1,italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥2italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥3italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥1italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¥41\frac{\phi(x_{2})-\phi(x_{3})}{\phi(x_{1})-\phi(x_{4})}\leq 1,

which is our claim. âˆ

We now show that, as a consequence of Theorem 1, if two of the masses are equal, there are strong restrictions on the shape of the allowed central configuration.

Proposition 5.

For any trapezoidal c.c. in Î©Î©\Omega, if either m2=m4subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š4m_{2}=m_{4} or m1=m3subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š3m_{1}=m_{3} the configuration is a rhombus and the remaining two masses are necessarily equal. If m3=m4subscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š4m_{3}=m_{4}, then the configuration is an isosceles trapezoid and the other two masses are necessarily equal.

Proof.

First we consider the case m1=m3subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š3m_{1}=m_{3}. By the proof of Theorem 1 we have that m1â‰¥m3subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š3m_{1}\geq m_{3} and the expression

m1m3=r143r233â‹…r122r342â‹…(r243âˆ’r343)(r243âˆ’r143)â‹…(r133âˆ’r233)(r133âˆ’r123)subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š3â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ143superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ233superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ122superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ342superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ243superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ343superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ243superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ143superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ133superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ233superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ133superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ123\frac{m_{1}}{m_{3}}=\frac{r_{14}^{3}}{r_{23}^{3}}\cdot\frac{r_{12}^{2}}{r_{34}^{2}}\cdot\frac{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})}{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{14}^{3})}\cdot\frac{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{23}^{3})}{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{12}^{3})}

is the product of three numbers greater than or equal to one. If m3=m1subscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š1m_{3}=m_{1}, it follows that each of the fractions in the equation above is equal to one. From the first two fractions we obtain r14=r23subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23r_{14}=r_{23} and r12=r34subscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ34r_{12}=r_{34}, respectively. From the last two fractions we obtain r14=r34subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ34r_{14}=r_{34} and r12=r23subscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ23r_{12}=r_{23}, respectively. This yields a rhombus. Moreover, comparing the two equation (14) we find that m2=m4subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š4m_{2}=m_{4}.

Second we consider m2=m4subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š4m_{2}=m_{4}. From the proof of Theorem 1, we have that m2â‰¥m4subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š4m_{2}\geq m_{4} and

This expression is the product of four numbers greater than or equal to one. If we require m2=m4subscriptğ‘š2subscriptğ‘š4m_{2}=m_{4}, then from the second fraction we obtain r14=r23subscriptğ‘Ÿ14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23r_{14}=r_{23}. Moreover, the first fraction now reduces to (r12/r34)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ342(r_{12}/r_{34})^{2}, and thus we must have r12=r34subscriptğ‘Ÿ12subscriptğ‘Ÿ34r_{12}=r_{34}. m3m4=r24âˆ’3âˆ’r14âˆ’3r13âˆ’3âˆ’r23âˆ’3subscriptğ‘š3subscriptğ‘š4superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ243superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ143superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ133superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ233\frac{m_{3}}{m_{4}}=\frac{r_{24}^{-3}-r_{14}^{-3}}{r_{13}^{-3}-r_{23}^{-3}}

r24âˆ’3âˆ’r13âˆ’3=r14âˆ’3âˆ’r23âˆ’3.superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ243superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ133superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ143superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ233r_{24}^{-3}-r_{13}^{-3}=r_{14}^{-3}-r_{23}^{-3}.

Hence, r23=r14subscriptğ‘Ÿ23subscriptğ‘Ÿ14r_{23}=r_{14} and r13=r24subscriptğ‘Ÿ13subscriptğ‘Ÿ24r_{13}=r_{24}. Since a trapezoid with equal diagonals is an isosceles trapezoid, the configuration is an isosceles trapezoid. The equality of the masses m1=m2subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2m_{1}=m_{2} then follows from the first of equations (20). This completes the proof.

Remark.
